title: Real Madrid 0 - 1 Barcelona : Xavi side edge tight Copa Clasico ( part one )
body_text:
As Clasicos go, you could say this will be a long one ‚Äî the second leg of Real Madrid and Barcelona‚Äôs Copa del Rey semi-final comes in over a month‚Äôs time, on 5 April.
And as Clasicos go, it wasn‚Äôt much of a classic, but on Thursday night it was Xavi‚Äôs Barca who earned an early advantage, hanging on to beat their rivals 1-0 in a tight game at the Estadio Santiago Bernabeu.
Here, The Athletic picks out some of the talking points and key moments of the match.

Barca don‚Äôt crap themselves (ahem)
Ever since 2006-07, when a Fabio Capello-coached Madrid made up a five-point deficit to overtake Barcelona and become La Liga champions, Bernabeu fans and pundits have loved to talk about a ‚Äòcagometro‚Äô (crap-ometer) that measures how Barca doubt themselves when things start to go wrong.
Blaugrana fans always reject the idea, but Xavi saying three different times at the pre-game news conference that Madrid were favourites for this game seemed to show how the Catalans‚Äô confidence had been hit by their two defeats in four days to Manchester United in the Europa League and Almeria in La Liga.
Madrid‚Äôs fast start looked designed to test Barca‚Äôs mettle, and Carlo Ancelotti‚Äôs team were well on top in the opening 15 minutes, with Luka Modric missing a super chance and Karim Benzema having a goal ruled out for a close but correct offside decision.
But Barca, bit by bit, interrupted Madrid‚Äôs flow, winning free kicks and making the game scrappier, with Franck Kessie and Gavi particularly effective in this. It worked in their favour as Ferran Torres took advantage of Eduardo Camavinga‚Äôs mistake for the opening goal, too.
It was not a goal for the tiki-taka purists but did suggest that this Barca team was not going to crumble when the pressure came on. And Barca‚Äôs performance overall suggested Madrid are going to have to do something special themselves to eat into their rival‚Äôs seven-point lead in the La Liga standings.
Dermot Corrigan
Camavinga slip-up sees fast start fall flat
Ancelotti could not have asked for a better start from his side: Madrid‚Äôs press was relentless, Modric became an extra forward at times and Barcelona barely had a chance to breathe. That was summed up when Frenkie de Jong tried to surge forward but was stopped by a Vinicius Junior headlock ‚Äî leading to a Barca free-kick and a bemused reaction from the Brazilian when he was shown a yellow card.

But that was all undone by Barca‚Äôs opening goal in the 26th minute, which stemmed from a mistake by Eduardo Camavinga. The France midfielder under-hit a backpass that Ferran Torres easily intercepted. The former Manchester City forward then offloaded for Kessie, who slotted home via comical interventions from Eder Militao and Nacho Fernandez. The goal was eventually given via the VAR, having initially been ruled out for offside.
Camavinga lost possession on a number of occasions during Real‚Äôs 5-2 comeback win against Liverpool, and his first-half performance at the Santiago Bernabeu showed why he has yet to fully establish himself in midfield. The 20-year-old‚Äôs best displays this season have come when playing at left-back, and he will need to show more composure if he is to convince Ancelotti he is worthy of a regular starting spot in his preferred position.

Madrid fans bring dodgy banknotes
This was the first Clasico since news emerged a few weeks ago that prosecutors are investigating payments totalling ‚Ç¨1.4million (¬£1.2m; $1.3m) that Barca made between 2016 and 2018 to a company owned by Jose Maria Enriquez Negreira. At the time, he was vice president of the Spanish football referees committee.

Enriquez Negreira has denied ever favouring Barcelona in terms of refereeing decisions. Barca have admitted to having hired an ‚Äúexternal consultant‚Äù who provided reports ‚Äúrelated to professional refereeing‚Äù.
Around 50 Real Madrid fans held a public display in the build-up to kick-off outside the ground, with the intention of throwing fake bank notes bearing the face of Barcelona president Joan Laporta towards the visitors‚Äô team bus as it passed by. Police officers were on hand to contain the demonstration, but within the ground too, fans were keen to make the affair a focus of their attention.

Ronald the right-back locks down the left
Barcelona have now won three of the last four Clasicos, and it‚Äôs no coincidence that Ronald Araujo wasn‚Äôt around for that one defeat (in this season‚Äôs first La Liga meeting).
Many of the recent matches between Spain‚Äôs two great clubs have revolved around an electric left-hand side, and tonight‚Äôs Copa encounter was no exception. Xavi perhaps could have predicted as much: 44% of Real Madrid‚Äôs attacking touches have come down that flank in La Liga this season, the most of any side in the Spanish top flight.
The source of that bias is clear. In his last seven games, Vinicius Jr has attempted 94 take-ons, at an average of over 13 per match. Under Araujo‚Äôs watchful eye tonight, the Brazilian dared to try just five.

That individual battle has clearly been a source of concern for Ancelotti, and he even tried moving Vinicius Jr into more central areas, in an attempt to drag the Uruguayan inside. Drafting Raphinha in to help with the overlapping full-back, however, saw Xavi‚Äôs back-line confidently deal with the rotations.
Vinicius Jr is no stranger to a tussle, but none have been quite so fruitless as Thursday‚Äôs showdown with one of Europe‚Äôs most accomplished defenders.
Thom Harris
Oh, Ansu!
In the second half, Barca were defending well but unable to find a second goal to really take control; their few chances to counter-attack not coming off.
Then came a clear chance for 2-0. Torres ran Camavinga on the outside and pulled back perfectly for Kessie, whose shot looked goalbound‚Ä¶ but hit Ansu Fati and deflected wide.
It was just typical of how things have been going for Fati, with all his struggles for fitness, form and confidence. Maybe Kessie‚Äôs shot was going to hit the post and needed a flick to divert it goalwards, but it never looked like Fati was going to take advantage.

It was not a dreadful miss ‚Äî not at all ‚Äî but still the sensation was all so different from a few years back, when every ball Fati touched around the box seemed to fly into the net. This was just another reminder that seems so long ago now.
Dermot Corrigan
Benzema still hit-and-miss
It was always going to be hard for Benzema to match the heights of last season when he helped Madrid to a La Liga-Champions League double with a career-best 44 goals in 46 appearances. But while the Frenchman is still Real‚Äôs joint-top scorer this season with 18 efforts in all competitions ‚Äî the same as Vinicius Jr ‚Äî there is something missing from his performances.
Benzema started brightly here, producing some fine link-up play to stretch Barcelona‚Äôs defence and create space for his team-mates. But the 35-year-old faded after Barca‚Äôs opening goal. He showed less all-round quality in the second half and seemed to go missing as Real searched for an equaliser.
Ancelotti brought on Rodrygo for Nacho in the 67th minute as he tried to give his team a cutting edge and youth player Alvaro Rodriguez was given a cameo late on, but it was no use. Madrid have struggled to replace Benzema when he has been absent through injury this season, with Mariano Diaz the only other out-and-out striker in the first team.
It is no surprise that Madrid are looking to sign another forward this summer given blunt performances like this but, in the meantime, they need Benzema to rediscover his best form. On Thursday, they didn‚Äôt manage a single shot on target.

Don‚Äôt play Barca at their own game
Throughout an intense opening 26 minutes, it almost looked as if Barcelona and Real Madrid had swapped shirts.
As a tenacious trio of Vinicius Jr, Federico Valverde and 37-year-old Modric snapped and hacked at heels deep into enemy territory ‚Äì contesting 15 ground duels, completing four tackles and committing three fouls in a fractious first half ‚Äì Barca, kings of the high turnover, were forced to taste their own medicine.
For Xavi‚Äôs side, however, it was a case of quality rather than quantity.

No team in Spain have won the ball within 40 metres of the opposition goal more often than Barcelona this season, and a coordinated attack on Camavinga was some of their finest work.

Expertly boxing their opponents into an awkward wide space, the trap was triggered as a loopy throw-in found the Frenchman with his back to goal, sparking Gavi and Kessie into life.
Manchester United almost completely avoided engaging with Barcelona in their own defensive third, going quick and direct as often as they could. It didn‚Äôt take Real Madrid too long to find out why.
